We are pleased to announce that beginning next Monday, Sept. 21, free meals will be available to all enrolled students of Davis School District.

The free meals are being sponsored by the Department of Agriculture and will run through Dec. 18 or until funding runs out.

Davis Connect students or students on a remote learning schedule can pick up Grab ‘n Go meals at any nearby school. District-issued ID numbers are required to pick up a meal and students must be present to receive the meal. Please check individual schools for distribution times.

Special diet options must be ordered by 8:30 a.m. through the kitchen manager at the student’s home school. Proper documentation is required.

Parents are also encouraged to apply for free or reduced meals through their MyDSD account so when the funding expires, the district can continue the benefit for those students.

Weather forecasts are calling for continued strong winds until at least mid-morning Wednesday, Sept. 9. In light of that, we are canceling school for all DSD schools Wednesday, Sept. 9, because of power outages, continued weather threats and highway restrictions for high-profile vehicles - which include our busses.

In order to make sure all students have face-to-face instruction this week, we will hold in-person face-to-face instruction on Thursday for Group 2 (students with last names L-Z) and Friday for Group 1 (students with last names A-K). In our secondary schools, B-day classes will be held on both Thursday and Friday. We know this is a departure from our previously announced schedule for the week, but it is important that students see their teachers at least once this week. Friday will not be an early out for students.

Even though Syracuse Elementary's Medieval Festival was canceled due to the school soft-closure, sixth-grader Zachary decided to build a castle anyway, which would have earned him King status for the event.

Students often use sugar cubes or cardboard to build a model castle, but Zachary decided to use all 2,099 Raisel boxes he had accrued during the past six years from his friends' school lunches. Normally, Zachary likes eating Raisels, but they accrued faster than he could eat them.

Zachary and his family spent a couple weeks building the Raisel castle, which features 15-box-high walls, four 18-box-high towers, a decorative platform and a rounded, drawstring door. To watch the entire process, click here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PLcCy28B2Gg&feature=youtu.be

Senior choir students at Bountiful High School were unable to sing in their final concert of the school year, so their choir director, Larry Smith, decided to create a virtual performance using their voices.

"I toyed with this idea from the day we started school closure. I wanted something for these seniors. I have never in my life edited sound and videos though,” said Smith. “I truly felt inspired every step of the way as far as how to make this happen. I just felt so strongly I had to do something for the seniors. It works out well at Bountiful High since my a cappella choir is exclusively seniors. I have shed many tears over this. I had the pleasure of watching every single individual video as they came in. There are a handful of simply ‘priceless’ faces to watch!" #dsdlearningfirst #uted #virtualchoir

As a ski racer at Middlebury College in Vermont, Chris Waddell knew things could go wrong during a competition, so he was prepared for the inevitable. That is, until a ski accident damaged his spinal cord, leaving him paralyzed from the waist down and taking his perspective to an entirely new level.

The 13-time U.S. Paralympic athlete and Hall of Famer spoke to Layton High students about perseverance after the debilitating injury.

“Breaking my back in a lot of ways was the closest to death I’ve ever come because it took so much of what I was, but it was also the most powerful I’ve ever been because I had to win the situation,” Waddell said.

“The situation was trying to squash me and trying to get me to quit, but each time I didn’t quit, I got a little bit stronger.” Read more here: https://www.davis.k12.ut.us/departments/cr/news-stories

The National Weather Service has issued a Winter Storm Warning that will remain in effect from 10 p.m. this evening to 10 p.m. Monday. Forecasts call for total snow accumulations of 4-8 inches, with up to 14 inches on the benches.

Due to that warning, the Davis School District will conduct a two-hour late start for all schools and facilities Monday morning. This means all schools will begin two hours later than normal, which will also include Head Start classes. However, because of that late start, all district kindergarten and pre-school classes will be cancelled.

In the event that weather worsens, the decision to cancel school will be made early in the morning. If that occurs, we will let you know by 6 a.m.

To reiterate, at the present time, we will hold school tomorrow, just two hours later than the normal start time.

What a score! Davis School District once again achieved systemwide K-12 accreditation and is still the only school district in the state to hold such a designation.
The accreditation comes after an 18-member AdvancED observed 255 classrooms and interviewed more than 700 people, including students, parents, community members and district personnel. The national average of AdvancED’s “Index of Education Quality” rating ranges from 278 to 283, but Davis School District scored 339 — a 53-point gain since the district’s original systemwide accreditation in 2014. #dsdaccreditedk12 #dsdlearningfirst #uted

post_text: The Davis School District, since Sunday, hosted an 18-member outside peer review accreditation team from AdvancED as it considered extending the district's K-12 systemwide accreditation. The group's work involved 723 face-to-face stakeholder interviews, 255 classroom observations at 27 schools and hundreds of hours of reviewing evidence of how the district operates and is progressing. Its official report to the district will come sometime in late November. Davis is the only district in Utah that currently holds systemwide accreditation, a distinction the district has had since 2014.
